Ever since the indie Metroidvania boom I've never found a game that really scratched that Super Metroid itch, until Environmental Station Alpha.

At first glance, the game's graphics will appear simplistic but you will eventually start to appreciate the level of detail that was put in. The animations in the game are well done, and each area seems handcrafted without a single wasted pixel. Some areas even have a dynamic feeling as they undergo change as the game progresses. The soundtrack is also great and fits the ambience of the mysterious station.

Gameplay wise it plays very much like you'd expect where you explore an uncharted area and fight bosses, while also finding tools along the way that allow you to explore more of the world. The grappling hook took you get is particularly fun to use. There are even a few optional upgrades you can get in the game, but they kind of end up making you overpowered.

The game tells it's plot in a wonderful way, where just as you explore the station like it's a puzzle, the story is the same way. It's a puzzle you slowly unravel and even includes a cryptic language for you to decipher to unlock the secret ending.

ESA also manages to mitigate some of the problems other metroidvanias have with backtracking by introducing a fairly substantial teleport system that allows you to easily transport yourself around the map to places you've already been. It introduces this just as the map really starts to open up more.

The only real drawback is the difficulty in the game is a bit uneven. Relatively early on certain boss fights will be on the difficult side, largely because you have limited health. However, during the end of the game most of the bosses end up becoming really easy thanks to having collected HP upgrades and some optional mobility/weapon upgrades.  Plus, as much as I enjoy the different bosses most of them don't involve a whole lot of movement. Instead they tend to be pretty stationary, and you need to dodge their attacks.  Luckily these are both flaws recognized by the developer, Hempuli, and something he is working on for the sequel!.

The game is only $8 and it is a great value, and should take you anywhere from 6 hours if you just power through the mainstory, to over 20 hours if your a completionist and go for the secret ending.

There's some good stuff to be found in Environmental Station Alpha, but unfortunately the game ended up losing my interest a few hours in. Despite ticking many of the right Metroidvania boxes, it was mostly the smaller nuances of the moment to moment gameplay that ended up turning me off.

First of all there's the art design. I'm not personally a big fan of pixel art once it starts getting too low-fi, but ESA looks pretty good regardless. I think the visual style of the game nails the ultra-retro vibe quite well. The problem comes with how this ties into gameplay. ESA doesn't do a great job of clearly deliniating different elements of the game world from one another, partially because of the lack of detail, but partially because the art direction mixes many similar shades together to the point where things that should pop out just don't. Platforms you can stand on, foreground vs background elements, and even some enemies suffer from this problem. It isn't a gamebreaker, but I found myself running into enemies I thought were background elements and falling through blocks I assumed were solid more times than I consider acceptable in a game like this.

Then there's the handling of progression and exploration. Most well designed Metroidvanias reward players who remember the locations of locked doors or inaccessible paths once they obtain the upgrade required to bypass them. Generally speaking, even if these pathways require multiple upgrades to navigate, you gate them off with the most difficult to obtain one first. That way the player is always rewarded for remembering the location and returning with the required powerup. ESA, by comparison, has several instances in which backtracking across the map mid way through the game only allows you to progress one or two screens further than last time, only to plant another progression blocker in front of you that requires something else to bypass. Certain elements of exploration and backtracking are punished in this regard rather than incentivised, with no way for the player to know that they should've waited to obtain more upgrades before coming back.

The controls and moment to moment gameplay in ESA are more or less good, but certainly not great. Double jumping, swinging, and shooting underwater after getting a certain upgrade can all feel pretty awkward and fiddly to execute at times. It certainly doesn't have the fluid, buttery smooth gameplay that you want out of a movement-heavy platformer, but it's not terrible either. I will commend the bosses for being very well designed around the game's control scheme, and overall I found them to be the most enjoyable part of the experience up to a point. The same can't necessarily be said for the regular enemies, however, with some of them being so bad as to simply charge at you and then stand inside your sprite until you shoot down at the floor to kill them. The adversaries with more fun movement and AI patterns are almost wholesale clones of Metroid enemies, and their stage placement sometimes feels haphazard as opposed to carefully considered.

What ultimately made me decide to put the game down was the age-old problem that often kills my motivation to carry on with a title: the feeling that it was wasting my time.
There were a few minor instances of this earlier on when failing jumps required me to backtrack across a screen or two largely devoid of challenge to reattempt them, but upon getting to an (otherwise very fun and memorable) boss that required me to go through two phases before getting to the part that was giving me trouble -- the first of which required me to sit around waiting until the boss revealed its weak point -- I decided I'd put enough time into ESA. I adore a good challenge, but I have little patience for games that force me to sit, wait, and repeatedly progress through trivial challenges before being allowed to reattempt the fun part. It's a shame, because up until that point I'd been happy to press on with the game on the strength of the boss battles alone.

Overall, I'd give ESA a mixed recommendation if I could. It captures the retro style it's going for very well despite the issues with visual clarity. The music is fitting, the art is neat, and as far as Metroid clones go this one does a similarly good job as Axiom Verge at evoking the same kind of amtosphere. The bosses -- time-wasting issues aside -- are incredibly good, with fun designs and interesting mechanics that challenge you to master their patterns and respond appropriately. Unfortunately it just has a lot of rough edges, lacking the tightness of a truly good Metroidvania both in terms of its controls and level design. I'll admit that I probably have higher standards than most when it comes to the genre, so take that into consideration when evaluating the helpfulness of this review, but compared to many of the Metroidvanias released within the last few years ESA just didn't hit the mark for me. It's almost there, but not quite.

Few would argue against the idea that Super Metroid is superior in every way to the original Metroid for the NES, myself included. However, I always felt that the Metroid franchise lost something along the way when jumping from 8-bit to the 16-bit era.
Sure, Super Metroid has better controls, better power-ups, better graphics, the list goes on. Its a much more polished  and mechanically satisfying game, and its one of the best player empowerment experiences out there. So much so that every single Super Metroid clone out there always tries to recreate that experience.
But it lost something. It lost the feeling of isolation and fear of being in an alien environment and the threat of getting lost and having to backtrack through rooms filled with dangerous species that could easily destroy you if you arent careful.
By now you must be shaking your head and saying that Super Metroid has that as well in spades. And yeah, I agree with that but that experience is really only felt in the first few hours of the game. Once you get into the groove of things in Super Metroid, small enemies cease to become a threat and you are just blasting through every level getting every power up that in turn makes you even more powerful. Bosses become easy targets, since your health gets so high you can tank them. The handheld Metroids are even more helpful to the player, showing them every single secret right away on the map, they just become a checkbox waiting to be checked. Its an easy game, is basically what im saying. There are no moments of real frustration and tension in Super Metroid. And I wouldnt have it any other way, part of what makes Super Metroid so great is that feeling of getting stronger with each room explored and how the final stretch of the game contrasts with the beginning of the journey.
But yet I still long for that feeling of constant danger and being lost in a hostile world.

I can now safely say that Environmental Station Alpha finally filled that void.
From the moment you step on the game's world you feel this sense of smallness and caution that few games manage to achieve. You are weak, your weapon is weak, the world is big and doesnt tell you were to go, and enemies surround and gain on you so fast you barely have room to breath. And it stays that way until the end no matter how many power ups you get.
And its hard, its beautifully fucking hard. Bosses are incredibly complex and challenging, and some of them even trick you into thinking that you killed them only for them to go to a 2nd more harder phase. The platforming is tight, every jump matters, and getting lost as you try to find the next path is, in retrospection, some of the best frustrating moments I have ever had with a videogame.
Every power up matters and drastically changes the way you play from then on. Take the grappling hook for example:what was a gimmick in Super Metroid that can only be used on certain surfaces, in ESA the item can be used EVERYWHERE. The platforming gets even harder, demanding you to use your brain and figure out how to approach certain jumps in combination with the hook without any handholding or condescending tutorials, it becomes a tool in use for the rest of the game, and using it is so much fun, especially since you can use it to move faster through areas.
The charge shot is a godsend once you find it, and unlike in Super Metroid where it easily gets disposed of when you get stuff like the Ice Beam or Plasma Beam, it becomes an essencial part of your strategy against every enemy and boss.  
Certain areas even change due to your actions, much to the players surprise, turning what were by now easy areas to traverse challenging all over again.
Finding a Health Tank is always a motive for celebration in this game, they are so well hidden and reward players who explore every nook and cranny, and there are so many instances where the game trusts you to make certain judgement calls and leaps of faith because it knows you have the capacity to solve those issues.

As for the world design, what can I even say? I took a look at a map of the game once I finished it and I could remember almost every single area and corredor, and if thats not a mark of good level design, I dont know what is. There is even a crazy amount of sequence breaking for speedrunners, showing how much work the devs put into this game.
The aesthetic and artstyle is gorgeous, and the simple yet effective pixel art leaves room for your imagination to fill in the blanks. The tunes are moody and atmospheric as you would expect from a metroid clone, and the diverse biomes are so memorable and different from one another, one area in particular that left me in awe due to its beauty and soundtrack.
The controls are also great, it doesnt have the floatyness of Samus, jumping feels very natural and responsive.

And there's secrets! Not the kind of secret that's spelled out on the map or that anyone can catch right away, but real secrets. Fez type of secrets. The kind that makes you solve riddles and puzzles to unlock post-game content that add much more value and story to the game. 

As you can guess, im infatuated by this game, its everything I wanted from a Super Metroid successor and it saddens me that this doesnt get as much attention as games like Axiom Verge, which while being a good game feels very soulless and lacking that Metroid mystique.
  
As for cons, they are mostly just nitpicks. While I appreciate the simple plot which serves as a vehicle for the gameplay, providing some context for your commitment to it, I wish it was a bit more interesting and less cliche, but then again this really isnt an issue, and the post-game does add more interesting lore to the game.
My other nitpick is that it doesnt have an escape sequence. I can understand not wanting to rip off Metroid, but the thing is, there is a moment where the station is being destroyed and you have to get to your ship as fast as possible, and the game simply shows a cutscene of you escaping. So why not put an actual escape sequence for the player?
It also might steal maybe a bit too much from Super Metroid, but it has such a unique presentation and style that it manages to differenciate itself just enough to not be considered a rip-off.

All in all, this might be the best Super Metroid clone I have ever played. Please give this game a chance if you have any interest in Metroidvania style games, I promise you wont regret it.

I didn't expect much going in, though I did hear good things about this game. It has an atmosphere and 2D exploratory gameplay most similarly to Metroid, a fact that is pretty much undeniable. Compared to other "metroidvanias," which take on an explicitly different theme or music style, Environmental Station Alpha wears its Metroid inspiration pretty openly on its sleeve. So Metroid fans who are big fans of the series' exploration and atmosphere would do well to check this game out.

Beyond its inspiration, however, it's just a well put-together game in general. Upgrades, bosses, and environments all open up at a very comfortable and easily digestible pace. There's a sense of weight to the robot you control, giving it a different feel from the somersaulting action of Metroid (I'd say the main character feels more like the Cave Story protagonist). Attacking is done with a continuous short-range stream rather than individual shots like in Metroid, giving attacking a more deliberate and precise feel as well. 

The map is huge, but not overwhelming, and teleport systems are all in the right places to facilitate fast travel without devaluing the exploration itself. Its biggest accomplishment, however, is the nigh-incredible use of landmarking and identity generously peppered across each and every single room in the game. ESA not only borrows from Metroid's atmosphere and gameplay, but also the distinctiveness of every one of any given entry's rooms. I can still picture the entire station in my head, how it all connects together, without needing to look at the map screen. No area in the game feels dull, and the way upgrades and switches change the landscape just beg further curiosity for the surroundings. In short, it's inspired by Metroid in the biggest way it counts--level design.

I suppose the only negative thing I have to say about the game is that it takes a while before it really gets going, since for a while all you can do is shoot and jump, but it all starts to pick up once you acquire the grappling hook (it's called a hookshot in this game, haha). It immediately makes for a rather fun way to traverse the environment.

It's hard to put into words just how well thought out the game feels, but it's what I'm focusing on because its outward appearance suggests that of a cheap Metroid imitation, so I understand this makes it somewhat of a hard sell. Nonetheless, if you can look past its similarity and try it out for yourself, I think you'll end up being pleasantly surprised with a new Steam favorite.

Long story short, this is a simple-looking but surprisingly complex and satisfying Metroid clone.  If you like Metroid clones, you should give this a try, period, though there are flaws.

I use Metroid clone rather than Metroidvania to describe it since it lacks any of the RPG elements usually associated with the -vania affix; this is pure, oldschool Metroid style, not unlike Axiom Verge or AM2R.  Of course, it's a bit less 'pretty' than those games, opting for an ultra-simplistic 8bit style with 8x8 tiles (rather than the 16x16 you'd usually see in this style of game), yet it still manages to get the job done with surprising flair and quality in this approach.  As well, the soundtrack's quite nice and aesthetically the game pulls off a great eerie, lonely atmosphere.  It basically pulls off something similar to Super Metroid's tone using only tools a bit closer to Metroid 1's, which is impressive in and of itself.

As far as gameplay goes, it's for the most part about as simple as this kind of game gets; you run, jump, and shoot, with upgrades that increase your ability to do most these things in various, simple ways.  Once or twice you'll encounter a somewhat unique upgrade such as the grappling hook which comes with a surprisingly deep physics system that allows skilled and clever players to sequence break with it alone, but most everything else is almost disappointingly bland given how crazy powerups in this genre have gotten (again Axiom Verge is a good example).  What's more, and this is the game's deepest fault IMHO, the feeling of increasing in power as you traverse the game -- perhaps the single most addicting element of this genre -- is stifled in myriad ways.  Not only are the powerups themselves generally small and rarely make you feel a full order of magnitude more powerful in and of themselves, but the game does all kinds of things to keep you feeling modest.  Most notably, as you go through the game and power yourself up, the station "comes alive" more and more and traversing the gameworld actually becomes [B]MORE[/b] difficult, even if you can techinically reach new places... though occasionally you'll even be locked completely out of previous zones until later still!  And even at the very end, when you're fully geared and the whole map should be your oyster, it's kind of a nightmare to get from place to place, even with the teleport system you unlock.  And on top of all that, the endgame is absolutely full of challenges that limit your powerups or force you to turn them off or punish you for using certain ones... it truly makes you feel almost bad for powering up at several points, and that's not a great thing.

And speaking of endgame... yeah... well.  It's hard enough as it is, definitely a challenging game to begin with and most the bosses will give you a run for your money until you've memorized them quite well, ESPECIALLY toward the end... but oh, no no no, even beating the difficult final boss isn't really the end, of course.  At this point you're meant to solve some intensely crazy, ARG-level puzzles throughuot the game, complete all kinds of wild challenges (several of which force you to turn off your meager powerups or punish you for using them, as stated) and complete "hell areas" to get the "real" ending, and... honestly? How does an indie Metroidvania stand out from its peers? The way Environmental Station Alpha does it isn't through a notable gimmick but rather through craft. It is a quality and cohesive title that, barring difficulty issues, could be a real treat for you.

It's the classic story of an abandoned research facility and an agent sent in to investigate where it all went wrong. The player takes control of a robot that will explore ES Alpha and discover the truth behind its downfall. Along the way the player will explore, fight, and powerup in traditional Metroidvania fashion. 

The powerups are cool and have that great mix of unlocking new areas in Alpha while assisting in moment-to-moment combat/traversal. You will explore many diverse regions of the Station that are memorable as they are fun to traverse. The game provides many interesting scenarios including the player speeding through a region while their health is slowly drained by the intense heat. These are interesting biomes that are fun to traverse the first couple times. That brings me to one of the game's few flaws. 

To get around, even with teleportation, you'll have to go over lots of ground that you likely have already trekked through because even with all the powers you obtain, the paths through ES Alpha are labyrinthian and don't open up as “wide” as they should. One must take the long way around to get anywhere, even late in the game. It can be grueling or tedious and it's only exacerbated by the game's difficulty.

Now I won't tell you if the game's difficulty is bad or not, but it's a hard game that can be unforgiving at times. For example, not only are a couple bosses very difficult and long, the game utilizes a very draconian save system. There is no autosaving, there are no checkpoints. The player must go to save rooms to record their game. If the player beats a boss and then dies without saving, the player will have to load in to their last save and do the boss over again and if there's a long gauntlet on the way to the boss, the player will have to do that too.

Bringing it back to the positive, ESA employs a pixel art graphic style that is one of the most considered pixel artstyles in modern indie games. The music is similarly great with lots of memorable ambient sounds that have real emotion and story behind them. The game's simplistic presentation goes very far.

ESA also has a very involved post-game (or extended ending, if you will). It highlights what's already interesting about the plot and expands on it. Warning though, conquering the post-game involves a cipher puzzle so if that bugs you, you might want to employ a help guide. The secrets of ES Alpha truly feel forbidden enhancing the otherworldly, alien tone of the game.

If you want a Metroidvania that relishes in its quiet, lonely tone and can tolerate some occasionally vicious difficulty, you'd be doing yourself a favour by checking out Environmental Station Alpha. It's engaging, it's interesting, and it's a real gem in the genre.

Teleporters can used to get around the station quickly.

[h1]Getting Lost[/h1]
Even though exploring is fun, be prepared to get lost. A lot. Areas that seemingly lead elsewhere are often out of reach with the player's current upgrades, or, there are hidden rooms behind walls that have little or no visual indication, contrary to other areas that may have cracks or color variation where blocks can be broken or passed through. Players may find that shooting and dashing at every wall conceivable seems like the only way not to miss something. There are times when the next destination is obvious, as certain events update the map with markers, but other times when players might feel at a complete loss as they try to decipher riddles.

[h1]Art & Soundtrack[/h1]
Environmental Station Alpha executes the retro feel excellently. The game features a darker, more neutral palette with pops of bright color that references the original Metroid and Super Metroid. The sound design appears to draw inspiration from those games as well. The soundtrack has Brinstar-like catchy tunes, but also has many atmospheric songs and sounds that enhance the feeling of isolation as the player delves deeper into the station's secrets. Some of the music gets quite eerie.

[h1]Writing[/h1]
The story is driven primarily by logs, so be prepared to read. I'm typically not a fan of story progression through text logs, but I don't mind it in ESA because the text logs are fairly short and sprinkled throughout. The subjects of these logs can seem confusing at first, but as players progress, more pieces of the puzzle are assembled regarding the events that transpired across the station before the robot's arrival. Some of these logs are filled with riddles, which may become clearer as they're revisited after exploring new areas.

[h1]Boss Design[/h1]
Each boss is a unique experience of varying difficulty and technique. There are a number of optional and secret bosses that test players' understanding of the game's physics. I find that the bosses of Environmental Station Alpha are a major highlight.

[h1]Secrets[/h1]
The game goes surprisingly deep with optional power ups, secret areas, an alien language, hidden rooms, easter eggs, and inside jokes, all of which the game doesn't spoil for the curious explorer. Close to--if not half of the game--includes the postgame secrets. Good luck to those that set out avoiding a guide for the postgame content. "Involved" is an understatement, but another area where Environmental Station Alpha shines.

[h1]Summary[/h1]
Gamers that enjoy the Metroid franchise will likely enjoy Environmental Station Alpha. It's undeniably influenced by that series, but most certainly no imitator. This isn't a cheap and short indie game. In fact, it's a big game for the low price. It is similar in length to Metroid, and even deeper with its secrets. For those that think they'll have Samus Aran's familiar arm cannon and powerups, they're in for a pleasant surprise.

It's good.  It's real good.  I am still enjoying the game thoroughly, even though I beat it hours ago.  It's one of those games that sucks you in while you're playing it, and stays on your mind when you're not.  The controls, graphics, atmosphere, and music all come together into a nice polished enjoyable experience.

I'll get the flaws out of the way first.  I really only see two, and they are quite minor:

[b]Pacing[/b] - If it's your second or third time through, the game probably plays fairly smoothly start to finish.  However, on the first try you will likely spend a fair bit of time searching for the next powerup, switch, or boss that advances the game.  I ended up revisiting the same dead ends a couple times, and this was occasionally frustrating.

[b]'One-way Loops'[/b] - The map is a necessity to the game.  However, often times when looking at the map it appears there may be two similar paths from your current location to the place you want to go, but only one of them is passable in the direction you are traveling.  It's sometimes very frustrating to almost get to your destination only to find out that “you can't get there from here”.  More than once the only way there is not the obvious way.

These are very minor gripes.  Minor, because of the nature of the game's strong points, like:

[b]Exploration![/b] - The game is large, and so much more full of variety than you could have possibly expected out of an 8x8 tile set and an “imaginary sound chip”.  There's so much to see and discover, and it all looks fantastic in its low-fi splendor.  Every portion of the station has its own look and atmosphere, its own enemies, and its own set of unique and interesting challenges.  So when you're not sure where to go next, just go somewhere.  It's nice there.

[b]Controls[/b] - The controls are tight.  They have enough predictability so that getting through a difficult area is much more a matter of practice than it is luck.  More than once I encountered a room or a boss where my first reaction was, “You've got to be kidding me, this looks impossible.”  However, after a few attempts (yes, you'll be retrying things regularly), the precision and repeatability of the controls becomes evident, and the completion of said room or boss is a very rewarding payoff.  Several times I found myself saying, “Wow!  I really pulled that off!  I'm amazing!”  Which brings me to:

[b]Rewards[/b] - Accomplishing a difficult series of jumps, finding that one secret spot that looks a little different than the others, and beating that punishing boss are usually good enough rewards in and of themselves.  However, occasionally you'll find an optional powerup that is just a joy to use.  You know what I'm talking about, because you've played other Metroidvania-type games.  It's that powerup that lets you go back through other areas that were difficult the first time, and completely tear them up.  Blasting through them so much faster than before while wearing a big stupid grin and giggling a little.  Yes, this game rewards its players for a job done well.

[b]Hints[/b] - Not really the obvious hints that tell you where to go next, but rather subtle hints like difficulty that say, “Maybe you should turn back.  This will be easier later.”  Usually if you encounter an area or enemy that seems unfair, it probably means you're headed in the wrong direction.  HOWEVER.  Several times throughout the game I stuck with it and muscled through an area ahead of schedule.  Not necessarily breaking the order of the game, but possibly to get a health or weapon upgrade a little early, so that I could have a little breathing room in the challenges ahead.  Very rarely was there ever an “all that work for nothing” situation.

[b]Atmosphere[/b] - The graphics, animation, and music put you there in the game.  Occasionally you'll spot inspiration from other beloved games in the genre, but it all really stands on its own, even if you're not bringing all that rosy nostalgia with you.  The water area is calming yet dangerous.  The lava area is close and oppressive.  The jungle area is verdant and lush.  At every point along the journey, the game draws you in to its amazing atmosphere.

[b]Free DLC[/b] - Yep.  The game received an update recently which included an optional new (seemingly large) area with new music, enemies, and graphics.  It's clear this developer enjoys their work.

Like I said, I beat it, but I'm definitely not done with it.  I'm not a completionist by any means, but the game still has so many interesting things to do that it will be keeping me entertained for a good number of gaming sessions yet.  If you've ever enjoyed a Metroidvania game, this is definitely one to add to your library, and it seems almost criminal to be buying it for under ten bucks.

P.S. My biggest request is for a Linux port.  Streaming it to a Linux machine has a number of issues that other games do not, and it has some deal-breaking control issues when played under Wine.  So if you want to play it on your Linux machine, you're fairly well out of luck unless you're better at troubleshooting strange issues than I am.  Since the game is built on MMF2, a Linux port (while not directly supported by MMF2) should be possible and mostly hassle free through a 3rd party library.  I think this developer has a bright future, and hopefully a Linux port can put a few extra dollars in their pockets, and help speed them along through their next project.

I don't generally recommend things in a public place, because it seems a little pointless, but I hope this helps someone make a decision.

I've played every 2D Metroid, I've dabbled in more recent Castlevanias, I've done a lot of platformers. ESA managed to hold my attention for over 75 hours of exploration, trying somewhat challenging things, and more exploration. This is Hempuli's first commercial release to my knowledge, but he spent about 3 years tinkering with this game and trying to make it better. This is a better-designed metroidvania than Super Metroid was. There's no arbitrarily huge amount of health that you need to recover by grinding off of little enemies spawning out of pipes. You find a save, you get your health back, you fan out in multiple directions and see if you can find anything. The only real negative I can think of when it comes to ESA's exploration is that you don't find some little missile pack buried in each room, stuffed in a wall. You don't get that momentary gratification and pointless increase to the capacity of a weapon you'll never use. Instead, when you find some health or a bonus item, you feel massively more rewarded. That's not for everyone, but it's certainly for me.

I see a lot of complaints about ESA stemming from its difficulty. "This boss has too many phases", "I don't have enough health", "I don't know where to go", all that kind of deal. The boss pacing definitely feels off in a couple of places. Some of the earlier bosses are decidedly more challenging than later ones feel at the time. The reason this doesn't bother me is because each boss actually feels very unique. Each boss has its own mechanics and feels complex in its own way, aside from a couple which are designed to teach you basic mechanics and one that acts as an item progression gate. Health, and dying a lot, are also not issues. There's an easy mode available directly from the start if you can't progress on normal, and it increases your maximum health, lowers enemy damage, and starts you with more maximum health. ESA also does a great job of directing you to where you need to be if you interact with terminals you find. Similar to Zero Mission, ESA will explain where you need to go through highlighting the target square on your map for you, which continues for quite a long time to allow you to continue progressing and exploring on the way to your destinations. You can also get around the game much faster than it initially seems due to the eventual introduction of a quick travel mechanic, eliminating a lot of pointless backtracking. Save points are generally positioned well and are used to prepare you for a boss so that you have a minimal run to get back to a boss. There are very few exceptions to this.

The amount of optional content in ESA is also very impressive. There are secrets hidden everywhere, optional upgrades you can find, and with the introduction of a recent patch an entirely new area to explore. On top of this, once you've beaten the main game and reached an ending, you may have some questions about things you have found in the past that seem to have had no effect. This is where your postgame starts, and there are plenty of clues about how to progress postgame that can be found simply by continuing to investigate each unfilled square on your map. The secrets of ESA are not like a missile expansion hunt you would experience in a Metroid game. They are targeted and explained if you look carefully. There are only a scarce few entirely self-contained bonus rooms having little to no indication of their existence; almost all the things you want to find have a directing point somewhere. The postgame secrets are handled in an entirely different way than the traditional metroidvania style and require a different mindset to continue delving into each step in the chain of hidden information, which is a wonderful changeup so late into the game.

The soundtrack was also handled very well. Every track fits into the area it belongs in and helps set the mood particularly well. The instrumentation used in ESA's soundtrack really goes well with the style of game and manages to call up memories of old SNES titles while not being some shameless ripoff. There wasn't a single instance where I felt "Oh, this track is obviously inspired by another game". My single complaint with ESA's soundtrack is the lack of variance in boss music. There's one track used for almost every boss in the game, and it became noticeable after a while. I definitely would have appreciated a bit of variance in the boss music, even if it was just one extra track on some bosses. Luckily, this isn't a huge issue, because most bosses are intense enough or go down quick enough once you know their patterns that the music doesn't feel repetitive.

The graphics are the only point where it starts to break down for me a little. For the most part, ESA functions visually, but there were definitely times where I felt that the player character was blending into the background a bit too much. The low-pixel style also impacted how enemies and environments appeared, and more than once I was a bit confused as to what I was looking at until I took a second to inspect it. This isn't a major issue, but I would personally have appreciated more pixel density for ESA so that I could better interpret what was going on in each area. It's easy enough to tell what you're looking at in 95% of the game, but that other 5% is what I wish had more to it. That said, each area in ESA is quite visually distinct and the environments never felt samey or repetitive. Each room, even, is visually memorable, which is pretty impressive.

Hempuli's put a lot of time into making ESA great. Any time a bug has come up, it's been fixed as soon as possible. There's still a persistent issue with some people running the Mac version where the game runs at decreased speed or lags, but from what I understand this might be fixed soon with a change in the Wine/Wineskin wrapper and is a result of a recent Mac OS update. Linux, unfortunately, does not jive with Multimedia Fusion. At the time of this review, your best bet is going to be playing this on Windows or using a dual-boot (which I guess people might have anyway because of Linux?), and the Mac version may be improved pretty soon to have few or no issues. There's one issue in particular where the Mac version will not support a controller natively, but using Joy2Key or any other program you like is a very quick workaround for this, and the keyboard controls function totally fine on their own. As far as the content of the game itself goes, bugs that have been reported to be negative for people have been ironed out pretty quickly, and nothing currently stands out as being broken. This is a game which has been examined and improved upon consistently since its release, and I really can't recommend it enough. Hempuli knocked it out of the park and has done all that was required of him as a dev, plus a free update with an entirely new area and its own secrets. Some people seem put off by ESA because of how it looks and from the apparently intimidating difficulty, but I promise that even a little patience goes a long way. I hope those who pick this up decide to keep at it even if a boss initially feels impossible or exploration feels initially unrewarding, because it is ultimately worth it.

To start: I used to add a much longer header to these reviews, but since it often made the reviews too long to submit, I've opted to leave it on my Backloggery.

Gameplay: This is one of those games that I would've had absolutely no interest in whatsoever if it hadn't been for a friend of mine recommending this game quite a lot. It's a Metroid-inspired platformer with retro graphics, so from premise alone it doesn't really have that "wow" factor that really compels me to play some games. After having played through it, I'll say that it wasn't the most inspired of games out there, but what it did, it did pretty well.

Of course, one of the most important parts of any Metroid-derivative game is the sense of exploration. At first, I was worried that the world seemed really small, given that the map at the time didn't seem exactly large. However, there's a lot within this map, and even by screen count alone, there's over 800 screens in the game. Even though it is a pretty big map, the map is very dense; there's a lot to do in this world, and even though it did get tiresome having to backtrack all the time when exploring the western side of the map, at least the rest of the map is very easy to explore. After a while in game you also unlock teleporters, which as mentioned in the previous sentence are pretty evenly placed with the exception of the desert and water areas.

Another big part of any Metroid style game is to have really cool powerups. I found 14 throughout my playthrough (although I've heard rumors of a soopur sekrit 15th), and while a few were either completely unnecessary (the rough map, for example really shouldn't be a powerup) or just served as an arbitrary gating mechanism (the keycard that unlocks golden blocks), there are a lot of really fun powerups as well. You've got standard things for a Metroid-esque game like the Heat-Resistant Suit and the Charge Beam, but there's also powerups that let you dash around all over the place, as well as a grapple hook which is easily the most fun powerup in the game.

This game also has bosses, and these sure are some bosses. While some of these bosses could do with either not having as many phases or having one health bar so that you know how many phases the boss has, almost all of these bosses are very fun to fight. There's only two bosses in the game that I would consider bad, and those are one boss where the only way you can damage the boss is to kite its projectiles back at the boss (a lot less fun than it sounds TBH) and a boss where it's impossible to defeat it without a certain powerup and stupidly easy to defeat with the powerup. However, for these missteps there are more than a few bosses which definitely make up for it.

Finishing the game for the first time took me about seven hours, but that's far from when the game is over. You can either choose to leave the game there or go on and play the post-game which can easily take you as long to beat as the main game does. While the mystery of unlocking pillars which are hitherto unknown to you is very cool, after a while the postgame turns into an insane amount of tedious backtracking and puzzles which are almost certainly way too obscure for their own good. I've played La-Mulana; I'm used to obscure puzzles, and while the now infamous Clock puzzle is cleverly structured, actually executing what has to be done to finish the puzzle just isn't worth it to me. As such, that's where I stopped playing.

Even though the post-game does get incredibly long-winded after a while, the main game is still a whole lot of fun, but one thing that concerns me is that, much like La-Mulana, all the magic is gone after the first playthrough once you know how to do everything and where to go. While the bosses are a load of fun, that's really all any subsequent playthroughs of this game are gonna be about. While unfortunately this game may be a "one-and-done" for me, at least it was a pretty solid one-and-done. 8/10.

Story: While I never got the third ending for completing the post-game (yes, this game has multiple endings), I did quite enjoy the writing of this game. It's written in a very sparse way, with some humor from time to time, but mostly detailing the crew attempting to survive from whatever the hell happened here on the station. While it does get a little overdone with its 2spooky-ness from time to time, it's still pretty well presented, and it leaves just enough for you to start filling in the gaps yourself. Not bad. 7/10.

Graphics: Well, you can tell from the store screenshots that this game is an 8-Bit pixel style game, and while that's far from anything terribly original, much like the gameplay it is at least done pretty well. The spriters made good use of their palette and screen royalty to give you some pretty damn awesome looking areas and enemies. Also, given that this game makes use of pixel art, you wouldn't expect any lag. Thankfully, I never had any lag throughout the entirety of the game. Resolution is a bit of a tricky spot, though; the game fullscreens by default, but renders as a square, leaving some pretty unsightly black bars on the sides. While this is something of a nitpick, I kinda wish they had done something like what La-Mulana did and have some graphics to the sides to at least make the screen feel a bit more full. Still though, the area, monster and boss designs are more than enough to hold your attention. Great job for the visual artists here. 5/5.

Sound: This game does have a tendency to feel a bit confused as far as the sound direction goes. Even though the game was "8-Bit," the OST feels like it would be more at home on an SNES. The sound effects feel pretty out of place from time to time as well; some of the sounds are realistic and some of the sounds are chippy. Even though this is pretty weird given the game's staunch insistence on looking like Metroid, at least the OST gets one thing right: ambience. While a couple of the songs get tired due to having to backtrack through a couple of areas (*cough* desert and water areas *cough*), each of the songs make the area feel like its own. It may not be the catchiest of OSTs, but it does its job well for providing atmosphere. Again, while the sound direction does kinda clash against the graphical direction from time to time, at least it works. 4/5.

Overall scores are: 8/7/5/4; cumulative score of 8.0/10. I'd definitely say there's enough to this game to easily warrant a full price purchase irrespective of supporting indie devs; there's just a lot of meat to this game. You may feel like throwing up after eating all that meat, but at least it was good before you threw it all up.

Environmental Station Alpha is a love letter to the original Metroid games, with a style and execution that is unique to the developer.  The game is the definition of a "metroidvania."  You are given a large, maze-like station to navigate, filled with puzzles, monsters, and bosses.  You expand your ability to reach areas by obtaining powerups, which primarily change the way you move through the game, although there are also weapon upgrades and the like.  

In terms of gameplay, this game does it right.  You are given the right amount of control over your character, and the movement and abilities feel good and work the way you expect them to.  The bosses have a great variety, and each fight feels and plays out differently.  Each new boss is an interesting and satisfying new experience.  The station is very well constructed, with a pretty good mix of dungeon and maze.  The station is also solid; there are no empty rooms or spaces inside the station itself, so there is lots to explore, and tons of hidden rooms to find.  

Graphics and Audio really shine in this game.  The graphics are charmingly done pixels.  Most of the environments are interesting to explore, and many are downright pretty.  At many points I was struck by the direct visual influences taken from Super Metroid, and they are done wonderfully.  The soundtrack is also fantastic, giving the right mix of mystery, hostility, creepiness, and alien strangeness.  

The main story premise is simple:  You are a robot sent to find out why the station went dead.  The story is advanced in small ways throughout the course of the game, given through some dialogue but mostly through computer terminals and logs.  The story is heavily one of mystery, however, so don't expect answers to all of your questions.  The game boasts multiple endings, and they are fun to unlock and see.

The game has a couple unique features to be mentioned.  First of all, once the game is completed, new objects and events appear in the station.  You are then able to undertake a new mystery (one that might take you beyond the station itself.)  This is done very well, aside from a couple frustrating moments, and it is absolutely worth completing.  Once this is done, you get an interesting little spin on the New Game + system, which you'll have to see for yourself.

It should be noted that this game is challenging.  I personally think it got the challenge level about right for most of the rooms, monsters and bosses.  However, players who are not experienced in some of the older and more challenging metroidvanias might find it a step up in difficulty from what they're used to.  Its a good kind of challenge, though, and anyone who enjoyed the original Metroids, Castlevanias, or more recent games like Cave Story should find the challenge level reasonable.  The mystery and extended end-game is tougher, but worth your time (and the forum is full of helpful posts by those who managed to puzzle most of it out first to help get you through.)  

This review got long, but only because the game deserves to have its virtues extolled.  It was a pleasure to play through this game, particularly as a lover of Metroidvanias (real ones, at that.)  Its also not very expensive, which is always a plus.

This is a genuinely great metroidvania.  It might be the best Metroid since Super Metroid.  The creator has produced a love letter to the genre that firmly deserves a place in it.  Its just that good.  For the price of admission, you honestly can't go wrong.

ESA is a game. It is a game about a space station. You as the protagonist is tasked in figuring out what has happened to it and its survivors. And that's about it for the story. Quite honestly, the fact that things are like that is fine for me. Although it does seem a bit same-y in terms of the sci-fi genre, the story is placed well not only with the various logs and computer terminals that are scattered about, but the environment and the atmosphere that each unique area presents.

The gameplay is [b]good[/b], and the item progression [b]solid[/b]. It feels similar in pacing to [i]Metroid Fusion[/i], but it [b]doesn't handhold you[/b], nor are there long lengths of dialogue or exposition (okay, maybe it's more similar to [i]Zero Mission[/i]). Enemies are distinguishable and have their own behaviours. All the bosses have their own strategies so you can't simply tank damage, and each battle a challenge to defeat. Each upgrade you get feels worthwhile and rewarding.

The sound effects of this game are [b]great[/b]. From the various bits and pieces of the station that are still running, the pitter patter of water in the caves, to the heated areas that is the Volcanic Sector--all of it combined with the soundtrack brings its own feel. The soundtrack is closer to the 16-bit era of music instead of the blippy chiptune noises you get from the current nostalgia-hype of 8-bit music, and it's [b]refreshing[/b] to hear it.

There's plenty of secrets to be had even if you finish the game. It doesn't pull the move of locking you into a predefined end-game path; the world remains quite open for you to explore. Health upgrades are pretty important items to find as later bosses take more hits to kill and find more ways to damage you, but that's not the only secret hidden on this station. I thought I'd seen everything, but then another one popped up.

It might be a while before I truly can consider myself 100%ing the game, but I can say that this game is [b]great[/b], and I recommend that you [b]buy it[/b]. Watch out if you think ESA is going to be easy. It's not.
